document_title: Celebrating 30 years of access to NASA Space Life Sciences data
summary_full: This paper commemorates significant anniversaries in NASA's space life sciences data archiving: 30 years of the NASA Ames Life Sciences Data Archive (ALSDA) and 10 years of NASA GeneLab. These archives are crucial for understanding the effects of space travel on biological systems and mitigating risks for future missions like Moon to Mars. ALSDA, established in 1994, initially focused on collecting diverse life sciences data, including experimental results, telemetry, and bioimaging, and played a role in developing the OAIS standard. GeneLab, initiated in 2014, specializes in omics data (genomics, proteomics, etc.) and has developed standardized bioinformatics pipelines and visualization tools. In 2021, ALSDA and GeneLab merged to form the NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR), creating a unified platform for accessing both legacy and omics data. OSDR now hosts over 500 studies across various life forms and is expanding its capabilities with AI/machine learning integration and collaborations with international space agencies, embodying NASA's commitment to open science.
key_findings: NASA's space life sciences data archiving efforts, through ALSDA and GeneLab, have reached 30 and 10-year milestones, respectively.
The merger of ALSDA and GeneLab in 2021 created the NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR), unifying diverse space biology datasets.
OSDR now provides access to over 500 studies across all life forms, with curated metadata and accessible raw/processed data.
Standardized bioinformatics pipelines and visualization tools have been developed for omics data within GeneLab and now OSDR.
Analysis Working Groups (AWGs) are actively contributing to data interpretation, meta-analyses, and the establishment of data standards within OSDR.
OSDR is actively integrating AI/machine learning capabilities to enhance data accessibility and reproducibility for future space missions.
future_research_fields: Leveraging AI and machine learning for enhanced data analysis and interpretation in space biology.
Further integration of data from international space agencies and commercial entities into OSDR.
Development of advanced biotechnological systems for human health and performance in deep space.
Continued research into biological responses to spaceflight hazards (radiation, altered gravity, confinement).
Expansion of data curation standards to encompass a wider range of assay types and data modalities.
conclusions: The integration of ALSDA and GeneLab into the NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) represents a significant advancement in space biosciences, fostering interdisciplinary, transparent, and inclusive research. OSDR, supported by a thriving community of Analysis Working Groups, is poised to drive new discoveries in space biology and health, embodying the maturity of open science in the field and aiming to expand its data offerings and leverage AI for improved accessibility and reproducibility.
impact_statement: This paper highlights the critical role of NASA's data archiving initiatives in enabling open science and advancing our understanding of life in space, crucial for future human exploration.
